Salutation from letter of 27 June 1862 In some ways, William B. Anderson's short letter of 27 June 1862 to his wife, Mary Louisa, typifies the twenty-one letters from William to Louisa that survive in the collection of the Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at The Ohio State University. It addresses three of the four broad topics about which he repeatedly writes to his wife during the summers of 1862, 1863, and 1864: managing domestic affairs and sustaining familial bonds when family members are separated for long periods by great distances; the rhetoric and logistics of mid-nineteenth-century correspondence; and the economic, logistical, and physical challenges of the riverboat business, especially on a waterway as critical as the Ohio River in the midst of the American Civil War (in other letters, Anderson also reflects more broadly on the uncertainties, vicissitudes, and suffering faced by civilians and soldiers alike in wartime).

However, this letter is also unique. All but two of the letters were written from Cincinnati, a thriving center of commerce on the Ohio River approximately halfway between its source at the confluence of the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and its confluence with the Mississippi River a mile or so south of Cairo, Illinois. The remaining letter in the collection was written from St. Louis, Missouri—though Anderson mentions writing from Louisville, Kentucky and Nashville, Tennessee as well. This letter was written from Pittsburgh, William and Louisa's home town. Presumably, he had been visiting his family and had expected to leave Pittsburgh by the Friday in late June when he wrote the letter; he writes to inform his wife of a delay.

As the collection in general reveals, delays were common, caused variously by negotiations over freight, water levels on the river, mechanical difficulties, and various military complications. Arrangements regarding freight seem to have kept Anderson in Pittsburgh overnight on June 27. He wants to secure a full load before leaving Pittsburgh because he "cannot depend upon getting any freight below here." He takes the opportunity to ask Louisa to send down "the Can of milk and 2 jars of lard and my clothes and overcoat." The definite article stands out: the Can of milk. One wonders whether, in his habitual haste (on which he often blames poor spelling and handwriting), he has simply rushed off and forgotten these items, and Louisa has sent him a note asking what she should do with them. In any case, in his haste to send her instructions, he crosses out the next two lines of his letter and recomposes them. Characteristically, the life of a riverboat captain seems frenetic.

It is also worth noting that he arranges to convey a note to his wife via "some one on the Shore at Shousetown." While the Andersons clearly handled much of their correspondence through the U.S. mail (he mentions post offices several times, and the collection includes one stamped envelope), they often convey both messages and goods through intermediaries traveling by rail or river.

Anderson's closing request constitutes something of a refrain in the letters. He asks Louisa to call on a Mr. Russell (probably John Russell, a local merchant) in order to collect money owed him, noting that he must meet his obligations on the crew's upcoming payday. Aside from suggesting that riverboat captains had to watch their cash flow carefully, this request reminds us that Louisa played a key role not only in caring for the Anderson household, including their four children (a fifth would be born in 1865), but also in tending to their business interests. Though we have only William Anderson's side of the correspondence, the letters reveal many details of Louisa's everyday life as well.

It is Louisa, presumably, whom we have to thank for initially preserving the letters, probably for the very common, personal reasons to which David Levy alludes in Scrolling Forward: Making Sense of Documents in the Digital Age: "In the privacy of our own homes we are likely to hold on to any number of treasures: cards, letters, and notes written long ago, photographs, scrapbooks filled with mementoes from an earlier era. We can't throw them out, even if we can't say why. We may look at them rarely or not at all, yet still it is somehow comforting to know they are there. It's as if something of importance is embedded in their very substance. This has less to do with their information content per se than with the emotions they evoke and the personal relationships they signify and embody" (96–97). The Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at The Ohio State University purchased the letters in part because they fit into a larger goal of acquiring materials that reveal the "common man's view of great events," and war letters are one focus of that larger effort (Smith). The collection as a whole, and the letter of 27 June 1862 more specifically, should also prove interesting to business historians and students of letter writing in American culture (Hewitt). The passing of time has made the everyday information in the letters newly valuable, though the letters also retain the power Levy speaks of to evoke the emotional fabric of everyday life, especially when it becomes frayed in the course of great events.

projectDesc.p: This edition represents a series of letters that William B. Anderson wrote to his wife, Louisa, at the time of the Civil War. During the war, Anderson piloted steam ships along the Ohio River, carrying freight and passengers alike. At this time, letter writing was the most effective means of communication, and the only way to keep domestic affairs in order.

The collection of letters penned by Anderson was purchased by the Ohio State Rare Books and Manuscripts library. They purchased the letters in an effort to increase their collection of wartime letters as well as documents that better illustrate the life-world of the historical periods that the letters were written in.

The reason for digitizing these documents is that the editors are trying to make these documents as easily accessible to as many people as possible. These letters may be of intest to historians interested in the Civil War, the Steamship Industry, or even postal historians. These potential readers were given the most careful consideration in designing the digital texts. The hope is that by making these annotated and edited documents available on the world wide web, that the documents will be "streamlined and tailored in the service of ever greater efficiency" (Levy 69). Hopefully, the rich media and annotations provided will help make these documents more easily understood while the technology itself makes them more widely available to interested audiences.

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of the Anderson letters emphasizes diplomatic transcription, with supplemental information allowing for semi-modernized, corrected, regularized, or expanded views included as the values of attributes associated with various elements. Accordingly, abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underscoring, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed or tagged as they appear in the original manuscripts. Regularized versions of all names and referring strings have been encoded as the values of "reg" attributes. Standard format values for all dates have been encoded in "value" attributes.

Corrections and emendations in Anderson's hand have been encoded as cancelations and interlinear or marginal additions. In a few cases, omitted text has been supplied by the editors for the sake of clarity and encoded with the TEI <supplied> element.

The following structural elements of the letters are also encoded: opener (including salutation and dateline), body, lines, paragraphs, pages, and closers (including salutation and signature). Notes and postscripts are identified as such.
The critical apparatus used in particular views of the letters is explained at the bottom of each view.
The XML and XSL files related to this edition are all available in the KB.

refsDecl.p: The XML files that constitute this edition of the William B. Anderson letters are named according the letters' dates of composition, using the following naming convention: WBA_YYYYMMDD.xml. Dates of composition were determined from various sources of evidence: the datelines inscribed in the letters, internal evidence in the body of the letters, and perpetual calendars. If the year, month, or date on which a letter was written could not be determined, the appropriate part of the filename is rendered with 0s. XSL style sheet documents are named with the prefix "WBA" followed by an underscore and a descriptive phrase (e.g., "WBA_diplomatic.xsl).

To facilitate embedding or linking to image, audio, and video files, this edition supplements the Text Encoding Initiative's DTD by adding a URL attribute to the <xref> element and an MMID (i.e., Media Manager ID) attribute to the <pb> element. The values of the MMID attribute in <pb> elements and the file IDs in the URL attribute of <xref> elements that link to, or embed, image, audio, and video files contained in the Media Manager are generated by the Media Manager application.

titleStmt.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his Wife, Louisa, 16 June 1862
titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: William B. Anderson writes home to his wife, Louisa, from Cincinnati, Ohio. He is hauling Coal Boat men from Louisville, Kentucky. While in Cincinnati, Anderson visits his mother-in-law, the 'old lady,' as well as family friends. During the dry, dusty, June weather, a fire breaks out near the Ohio River and Third St, destroying several houses. He opens his riverboat up as an improptu shelter for the fire victims, even filling the typically unoccupied Ladies' Cabins. Anderson closes the letter by inviting Louisa to accompany him on his next trip to Cincinnati.

physDesc.p: William B. Anderson's letter dated June 16, 1862 from Cincinnati and addressed to his wife Louisa is written in ink on two sides of a loose sheet of paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 9.0 inches tall (19 x 23 cm) and ruled with horizontal blue lines spaced .33 inches (0.8 cm) apart, except for a 1.5-inch (3.8 cm) unruled top margin. The left edge of the sheet is slightly ragged, while the other three edges are clean, suggesting that the sheet was torn from a notepad or bound notebook. It appears to have been folded in half once. Anderson indicates that this letter written in two seperate sessions. A .5-inch by .5-inch (1.3 x 1.3 cm) embossed printer's mark appears in the upper left- hand corner of the sheet, 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) from the top edge and .25 inch (0.6 cm) from the left edge. Although the mark is indistinct, its shape closely matches that of a distinct, similarly sized and positioned printer's mark on a letter dated July 1, 1863, which reads "MT HOLLY PAPER CO."

titleStmt.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa, 27 June 1862.
titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: Anderson tells his wife that his boat's departure has been delayed by a day and asks her to send some food and clothes to him at the dock. He also expresses anxiety about whether his trip will be profitable and asks his wife to request some money from [John?] Russell to help cover an upcoming payday for his crew.

titleStmt.title: Personal letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa, 11 July 1862
titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: Anderson tells his wife that his boat will attempt to beat another riverboat to Murraysville, WV. He explains that his sleep has been restless, inquires about their two sons and asks her to write more and to write back regarding business prospects. He is rushed, and signs off three times.

address.placeName: CinThe "2" is somewhat unclear. It resembles a "4". However, later in the letter, the author tells his wife to "be sure to write as before" and that he has "enclosed an envelope in yesterday's letter. The day before (Friday) July 11, 1962 would have been a Thursday, whereas the day before (Monday) July 11, 1964 would have been a Sunday. Assuming the author literally enclosed and mailed a letter containing an envelope, the date must be 1962 as he could not have sent mail out on Sunday.

titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: William B. Anderson's letter was addressed to his wife, Louisa, telling her that he was glad to hear about her welfare and also to hear about the kids doing well. William says in the letter that the war is far from over even though some people might think otherwise. William also ask Louisa to write him back when she gets a chance because from the time he gets back he'll have another letter waiting.

titleStmt.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa, 10 August 1862
titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: In this letter Anderson assures his wife that he is doing well and asks how she and the children are. He also tells her of his visit to see her mother and that he has asked John Russell (a local businessman often referred to in Anderson’s letters) to pay his taxes in his absence.

physDesc.p: William B. Anderson's letter dated August 10, 1862 from Cincinnati and addressed to his wife Louisa is written in ink on both sides of a loose sheet of paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 10.0 inches tall (20cm by 24.5cm) and ruled with horizontal blue lines spaced about 0.75cm apart. The left edge of the sheet is slightly ragged, while the other three edges are clean, suggesting that the sheet was torn from a notepad or bound notebook. It appears originally to have been folded once crosswise and three times lengthwise. At this writing, the ink appears dark brown and the paper off-white (cream).

as far as Gallipolis & if such should be
the case then I will be Free from the draft
I will expect a letter here when I return
which will be on this day week I will drop
you a line tomorrow before we leave and
let you know what our prospects are Kiss
all the children for me and take care of yourself
and them for me

titleStmt.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to wife Mary Louisa Anderson on August 16, 1862
titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: In this letter, Anderson writes to his wife about his daily tasks and his hardships while being a riverboat captain. He reports that a shaft has broken on the boat, and hopes the new part will arrive soon. Anderson continues his letter and describes how he feels about boarding soldiers on his riverboat. His emotions of grief and sadness overrun the second half of his letter, and he explains that he feels terrible watching families be torn apart. Anderson closes with warm wishes to his family and that he hopes to hear from them soon.

physDesc.p: William B. Anderson's letter dated August 16, 1862 from Cincinnati and addressed to his wife Louisa is written in ink on two sides of a loose sheet of paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 9.0 inches tall (19 x 23 cm) and ruled with horizontal blue lines spaced .33 inches (0.8 cm) apart, except for a 1.5-inch (3.8 cm) unruled top margin. All four edges of the letter, are clean, suggesting that the sheet was bought as a package of looseleaf. It appears originally to have been folded once crosswise and twice lengthwise. At this writing, the ink appears brown and the paper off-white (cream). A .5-inch by .5-inch (1.3 x 1.3 cm) embossed printer's mark appears in the upper lefthand corner of the sheet, 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) from the top edge and .25 inches (0.6 cm) from the left edge.

dateline.note: Anderson records the day as Sunday, but in August 1862, the 16th fell on a Saturday.

div.p:
As John is going home I take
the opportunity of dropping you a few lines
to inform you that I am well. We arrived here
at noon today we have had bad luck since
I wrote you last. We broke our shaft on our up
trip and shall have to lay here for several
days to have it mended or probably a
new one made. I cannot learn what our
luck will be in getting it repairedrepared till Morning
I will probably get time to go up and see
you while the repairingreparing is going on if I can
leave with any kind of propriety. It was one
of the worst times that an accident could
happen as the river is low and Government
wants us and at good prices we were pressed
into GovernmentGov Service at Gallipolis but were released
on account of our broke shaft
We brought down part of 3 companies of
soldiers from Gallipolis to camp Portsmouth
and it would have made the hardest heart
melt to have heard the women and children
weeping on the wharf Boat while the men
were being ordered on board there was at least
70 women & 100 children there to take perhaps
the last leave of their husbands Brothers & Sons
who have answered the call for men
to try and restore peace and restore this
once Glorious Country to peace. You see
or Know nothing about this war or the
effects produced upon families [deleted word] by it
I am sick and tired of soldiers and soldiering
we see nor hear but little else and what
I am most fearfull of is that the end is
not close at hand we carry every trip more
or less sick and wounded men and any amount
of women on their way to look up their sons
Husbands or Brothers while I am writing the
wharf is covered from Broadway to Main
street with fresh recruits from Indiana &
Ohio on their way to the Little Miami RailroadRR
Depot on their way to Camps to be uniformed
I have not been down today to see your mother
but will before I write again or go up
to see you I will not get to more than
just go up one day and return the next
if I do go at allal. Write to me soon and
give me all the news and take care
of yourself and all the children
you need not be disappointed if I don’t
go up through if I can learn alot I will
be sure to write to me as soon as you
get this in care of Isham Fisher & Co CincinnatiCin
give my love to the children

titleStmt.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Mary Louisa Anderson, on September 1st, 1862 from Cincinnati, Ohio.
titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: In this document, William B. Anderson lists his itinerary and the business conducted at each port of call. He brings oats to Gallipolis, Ohio; retrieves wheat from Graham's Station, West Virginia, and brings it to Blennerhasset's Island, West Virginia. During his travels, it was necessary to build a chute and hire oxen in order to bring the wheat to Blennerhasset's Island. In the latter part of the letter, Anderson discusses his hope to sell his boat, as business is stopped now that the previous travels are finished. He finishes by sending his love to his wife and children.

physDesc.p: This document is a letter from Captain William B. Anderson (1822-1897), to his wife, Mary Louisa (Fischgens) Anderson. He wrote this from Cincinnati, on September 1st, 1862. It is one page long, with no other notes or enclosures. It is written on lined notebook paper, folded in half lengthwise and into thirds after that. There is no surviving envelope that goes with it, and it is approximately eight inches by ten inches in size. There is a printer's mark in the upper-left hand corner, in the shape of a shield surrounded by greenery, with a crown on top. The left edge of the paper is slightly ragged and worn, as if it had been torn from a composition book or a pad of paper bound on the left.

div.p:
Yours came safe to hand & I was
glad to hear from you though sorry to hear that
all was not well but hope that before this all are
fully recoved. I have been quite unwell since I left
here but have got better so took a load of Oats
for the Government up to Gallipolis and from there
we went up to take our Wheat that we left
at Grahams Station and and succeeded in getting
up as far as the foot of Blennerhassets Island
and there we dug a chuteShute wide and deep enough
to draw a flat drawing but 13 inches over and at
3 lads got our wheat over and then hired a man
and a team of oxen to haul the flat offof and left
the 2nd clerk there to attend to it we arrived here
this morning and will leave at noon for Maysville with a
load of Mules and then I don’t know what we will
do though on our return I will write again I am
quite busy now but will probably have more time
to write about when I come back again I
may sell the boat I will try to anyhowany how
I hope to be home soon and will most
likely lay up if I don’t sell things are very
checkered and all businessbussiness is stopped give my
love to the children and take care of them
and you

titleStmt.title: A homesick letter to Mary Louisa Anderson written from Cincinnati on Sept. 17, 1862, by William B. Anderson
titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: In this letter, Anderson shows a bit of emotion as he recounts his encounters with the war thus far. Anderson writes of the impoverished life he and his fellow shipmates live and becomes nostalgic over the simpler pleasures in life like Butter [sic] and Beef [sic]. Anderson asks his wife to pay a vist to John Russell in order to collect the money that Russell owes Anderson; Anderson fears that Russell will be slow to repay if his wife does not express a strong sense of need. Anderson closes the letter optimistically speaking of great times to come with his wife and children once he returns home.

physDesc.p: This letter in written on a single thin piece of blue-lined paper as the writing on the opposite side shows through. The singular, vertical jagged edge on the left side of the paper suggests that the paper was torn from a notebook or journal. The paper is approximately 8 x 9.75 inches in dimension. Anderson wrote the letter in brown ink and folded the letter three times( once crosswise and twice length-wise) to create six equally-sized sections so that the letter could fit into one of his standard envelopes. On the bottom of the first page, several words are smudged perhaps as a result of moisture on the captain's hand from the summer heat or from a rapid writing pace that did not allow the ink to dry sufficiently.

div.p:
Yours Came to hand this morning
& I was glad to hear from you and pleased to learn
that the the children were well I am also well and
am still employed in the same way as a dispatch
Boat and our trips only extend down as far of late
as Andersons Ferry 8 miles we made but two yesterday
one at noon and one in the night all is quiet here
now and the majority of the stores are open but there
is nothing doing but what appertains to the war it
is thought that there will be a Battle in Kentucky
someplace soon but as it will not be in the vicinity
of the River I will not get a chance of witnessing
it I have heard so much of war and been so much
among soldiers that I have lost all horrors that I
used to entertain about war I would as soon go
to war as not if I were stout and had no family
for it has almost became a fashion to go all that
are left out of the military ranks are old and
decripped, and it seems as that it has became a
necessity to turn out. I will never go unless compelled
to and that in defence of my own property and for
the preservation of the Union I am sure that the South will
be completely broken up and the north greatly in
debt though the debt will be amongst the north
and the money will be left in the country and all
will be benefitted more or less with it.
over
I have not seen your mother since I last wrote
to you as I have to stay on the BoatAnderson built the Glide, a river steamer which he eventually sold to the U.S. government.Jordan506. I have no
opportunity of seeing any body or any thing only soldiers
guns and Cannons. We are almost tiredtiard of this kind
of work we live almost miserablymisserably poor I have not
tasted any Butter for 4 weeks that I could stand and
as for sauce we never have any thing of the kind we
have Beef poor at that and Bakers breadBred and the poorest
Kind of vegetablesvegatibles I ever saw all kinds of marketting is dur
and poor the Country is as dry as a chip for all we have
showers frequenty yesterday and last night and today
is as warm a time as we have had this summer and the
Mosquitoes are the worst I ever saw. I wish you would
Call on John Russell and tell him you want some
Money and keep all that you know to be good such
as U.S. and all Pittsburgh Banks I fear that I shall
fail to get all out of him if I don’t make frequent calls
you must let on to him that you are in need or he will
put you off. Tell all the children that I am not
in war nor do I intend to go that I will come home when
the river raises and that I have some things for them
I have a fine lot of Peach stones and watermelonwattermellon seeds
saved and I will go up town some of those days after
businessbussiness resumes more fully and buy each of them some
thing that will please them. I have thought frequently
about about our whereabouts and pleasures nine years
ago, and how as you thought what may our position
be nine year from now. I hope that we may have no
more to mar our happiness than we have had and
that we may both live and our children live many nine
years to come. I will stop as my paper is full I will
look for a letter from you on receipt of this and hope to
hear of you and the little ones enjoying good health and happiness

titleStmt.title: Letter from William B Anderson to his wife, Louisa, dated September 28, 1862.
titleStmt.author: Anderson, William B.

msIdentifier.repository: Rare Books and Manuscripts, The Ohio State University

msContents.p: William B Anderson tells his wife how he must take soldiers to Augusta, Kentucky. Anderson reports that he is doing well and that he is happy to hear that his wife's mother is also doing well. He wants his wife to take care of herself and the children. He describes when he thinks he may be home and for his wife to take care of the house and the work that needs to be done.

physDesc.p: This document is letter number 10 from a man named William B. Anderson that he wrote to his wife, Louisa in September of 1862 from Cincinnati. In all, there were 26 letters written to Louisa from 1862 to 1864. This particular letter is 2 pages long and is written on loose paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 9.0 inches tall, lined with blue horizontal lines. The first page of the letter is in pretty good condition. However, there are numerous brown stains that could possibly be dirt. The second page of the letter is in slightly better condition, with only a few smudges. Both pages seem to have been folded, twice long ways and once shorts ways. While the ink is black and legible throughout, there are still errors both in spelling and with ink smudges. The paper William used is a cream color.

div.p:
I am ordered to take up
a lot of Soldiers to Augusta Ky as the

it we are to take up a lot of men and

the Rebels if they can I will land

shot. I will write a full accountacct on our
return I have no time to write much now,
your Mother was here yesterday and is well
I am well & Hope you and all the children

and that of the children. I wrote you

yours yesterday and am sorry that Willie

give my respects to all and write
often and longer I yesterday learned what

say nothing about it I hope to stay here
Some time yet
